Hotel Transylvania 3: Summer Vacation

This movie was honestly super cute and a refreshing continuation of the Hotel Transylvania franchise. By the third installment, you might expect things to feel stale, but instead it’s full of life, color, and heart. One of the sweetest elements is seeing Selena Gomez’s character, Mavis, now a mother. That dynamic adds a whole new layer to the story, because not only do we see her relationship with her father, Dracula (voiced by Adam Sandler), but we also see how she balances being both a daughter and a mom. That family thread really grounds the comedy.

Adam Sandler once again goes all in as Dracula, bringing the same wild and goofy energy that’s been consistent since the first film. His exaggerated voice work and zany antics never get old, and in this film, his story is tied up in themes of loneliness and unexpected love, which makes him more relatable than ever. The fact that Dracula finds himself falling for Ericka, the cruise ship captain (who also happens to be connected to his greatest enemy, Van Helsing), creates the perfect blend of humor and heart. Their back-and-forth romance is surprisingly charming, with plenty of laughs along the way.

What makes this entry stand out is the vacation setting itself. Moving away from the hotel was a smart choice, giving the characters a new environment full of wild possibilities. The cruise ship, the Bermuda Triangle, the underwater volcano scenes — all of it is so vibrant and creative. It gives the animators room to really play, and visually it’s the most fun of the three films.

Comedy-wise, this is probably the funniest Hotel Transylvania movie yet. The family dynamics are more exaggerated, the slapstick gags land harder, and the use of modern music and dance battles (yes, there’s a full-on EDM showdown with Van Helsing’s monster-destroying device) feels ridiculous in the best way possible. Kids will laugh nonstop, but adults will also catch themselves chuckling at the clever timing and over-the-top chaos.

As for the series overall:
	•	The first film was fresh and creative, setting up the world and characters.
	•	The second film, in my opinion, got better, especially with the addition of Mavis and Johnny’s son and the generational humor.
	•	But the third film might just be my favorite. It feels like the most balanced — funny, sweet, colorful, and surprisingly heartfelt.

No, these characters aren’t the kind that you think of when naming your all-time favorite animated icons, but they don’t need to be. They’re fun, they’re lovable, and the world Genndy Tartakovsky has built is consistently creative.

Overall, Hotel Transylvania 3: Summer Vacation is lighthearted, family-friendly fun with a lot of comical moments. It might not be groundbreaking, but it doesn’t have to be. It’s pure entertainment, and I’d definitely recommend it for both kids and adults looking for something silly, sweet, and joyful.
